did.unittitle: Robert and Truman Abbe scrapbook on radium

bioghist.p: Robert Abbe (1851-1928) was an American surgeon and pioneering radiologist in New York City. He received his S.B. from the College of the City of New York in 1871 and his M.D. from Columbia University in 1874. In 1904, after corresponding with Marie and Pierre Curie about their research on radiation, he visited their laboratories in Paris. Abbe returned to the United States with samples and began experimental therapies for cancer treatment. Today, he is known as the founder of radiation therapy in the United States. Abbe suffered from a rare form of anemia toward the end of his life that may have been the result of exposure to radiation. He was a Fellow of the College of Physicians of Philadelphia. Truman Abbe (1873-1955), nephew of Robert Abbe, was born in Washington, D. C. and graduated from Harvard University in 1895. He received his degree in medicine at Columbia University in 1899, and then pursued post-graduate studies at the University of Berlin. Abbe began work in 1902 at Georgetown University and was appointed instructor there in 1905. In 1907, he was awarded a silver medal at the Jamestown Exposition for his research on the uses of radium in medicine.

scopecontent.p: The collection includes a scrapbook and loose items relating to the early research on and early history of radium. Included are original research notes, newspaper clippings, telegrams, reprints, and sales notices. The material dates from 1903 to 1950, and contains two items signed by Marie Curie, the discoverer of radium.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: Cornell University Library, Kroch Library Rare & Manuscripts: George Waldo Abbe and Charlotte Colgate Abbe letters; National Library of Medicine: Truman Abbe papers.
